rename.from: syncthing-inotify + syncthing leading to dropped updates.
rename.to: syncthing-inotify + syncthing leading to dropped updates with common prefixes

body: I did a rollback test.  The last working version is 0.12.15.  0.12.16 through 0.12.20 are broken with "touch foo.txt foo.txt.sig" in the root of a synced folder and syncthing-inotify.

Thanks for doing the rollback investigation. It's very likely that my fix for #2151 uncovered a deeper issue with syncthing-inotify that causes it to drop some events without passing them on to syncthing.
I ran syncthing-inofity with -verbose=4. It is passing all the events to syncthing, and syncthing is acking them them all.

I've discovered the behavior is different for previously known files.

The first time I test with a pair of files behaves differently to subsequent times I test with them.  eg: a test run with "bar.txt" and "bar.txt.sig" for the very first time:

```
peter@overcee[ 7:14PM]~/Sync-1041> touch bar.txt bar.txt.sig
...
[DEBUG] 19:14:24 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt.sig (could still be ignored)
[TRACE] 19:14:24 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:14:24 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt (could still be ignored)
[TRACE] 19:14:24 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:14:24 [FS] Tracking: bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:14:24 [FS] Tracking: bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:14:24 Timeout AccumulateChanges
[DEBUG] 19:14:24 Informing about bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:14:24 Informing about bar.txt
[TRACE] 19:14:24 Informing ST: default: [bar.txt bar.txt.sig]
[TRACE] 19:14:24 Requesting STEvents: 363928
[TRACE] 19:14:24 Requesting STEvents: 363929
[OK] 19:14:25 Syncthing is indexing change in default: [bar.txt bar.txt.sig]
[DEBUG] 19:14:25 [INFORMED] Removed tracking for bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:14:25 [INFORMED] Removed tracking for bar.txt.sig
```

On a remote machine, I ended up with:

```
-rw-r--r--   1 peter  peter         0 Mar 17 19:14 bar.txt.sig
-rw-r--r--   1 peter  peter         0 Mar 17 19:14 bar.txt
```

Then deleting them:

```
peter@overcee[ 7:16PM]~/Sync-1042> rm bar.txt bar.txt.sig
...
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt (could still be ignored)
[TRACE] 19:16:37 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt.sig (could still be ignored)
[TRACE] 19:16:37 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 [FS] Tracking: bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 [FS] Tracking: bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 Timeout AccumulateChanges
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 Informing about bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 Informing about bar.txt.sig
[TRACE] 19:16:37 Informing ST: default: [bar.txt bar.txt.sig]
[TRACE] 19:16:37 Requesting STEvents: 363956
[OK] 19:16:37 Syncthing is indexing change in default: [bar.txt bar.txt.sig]
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 [INFORMED] Removed tracking for bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:16:37 [INFORMED] Removed tracking for bar.txt.sig
```

The files were deleted from the peer, as expected.

Now, creating them again:

```
peter@overcee[ 7:18PM]~/Sync-1043> touch bar.txt bar.txt.sig
...
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt.sig (could still be ignored)
[TRACE] 19:18:17 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt (could still be ignored)
[TRACE] 19:18:17 Change detected in: /home/peter/Sync/bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 [FS] Tracking: bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 [FS] Tracking: bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 Timeout AccumulateChanges
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 Informing about bar.txt.sig
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 Informing about bar.txt
[TRACE] 19:18:17 Informing ST: default: [bar.txt bar.txt.sig]
[TRACE] 19:18:17 Requesting STEvents: 363977
[TRACE] 19:18:17 Requesting STEvents: 363978
[OK] 19:18:17 Syncthing is indexing change in default: [bar.txt bar.txt.sig]
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 [INFORMED] Removed tracking for bar.txt
[DEBUG] 19:18:17 [INFORMED] Removed tracking for bar.txt.sig
```

And the remote didn't get "bar.txt.sig"

```
-rw-r--r--   1 peter  peter         0 Mar 17 19:18 bar.txt
```

Well, I can reliably reproduce the situation where the `.sig` file doesn't appear in syncthing's index after
`rm -f foo.txt foo.txt.sig; touch foo.txt foo.txt.sig`
according to
`curl -s http://localhost:8384/rest/db/browse?folder=default | json_pp`
but the annoying difference is that I'm not seeing things like
`Syncthing is indexing change in default: [foo.txt foo.txt.sig]`
My log only shows
`Syncthing is indexing change in default: [foo.txt]`
ie: syncthing-inotify doesn't tell syncthing about the `.sig` file. Also syncthing with`STTRACE=scanner` only shows
`walk.go:100: DEBUG: Walk /home/plouj/Sync/ [foo.txt] 131072 &{[] true 0xc820117a40 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc82045cb40 0xc820490a60}`
I can reliably reproduce this on syncthing master (bea272c).
What version of syncthing-inotify do you use?

Even with the latest version (master) of syncthing-inotify I see
`Syncthing is indexing change in default: [foo.txt foo.txt.sig]`
in the syncthing-inotify log, but only 
`Walk /home/plouj/Sync/ [foo.txt] 131072 &{[] true 0xc82019a6e0 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc8200b3260 0xc82047e890}`
from syncthing.
Seems like the `.sig` files get lost during the [unification](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/lib/model/model.go#L1322). If only it was a function that we could unit test... :)

From a bystander's point of view, the code near [model.go](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/lib/model/model.go#L1336) looks like it's intended to be used on exact matches of directories. string.HasPrefix() doesn't seem right - consider "usr/lib/..." vs "usr/libexec/...".  "usr" is a prefix of "usr/lib", while "usr/lib" shouldn't be considered a prefix of "usr/libexec" from the point of view of a path walk.

FWIW; the cluster that was having the initial problems ("admin-built" folder) was running syncthing-inotify-0.6.7 (vs current 0.6.8).  I used a different machine with the "default"folder was unpatched 0.6. (!). I'll go and update those now.

It would be interesting to see this with STTRACE=scanner to see what we actually do scan when being notified like this. Obviously the difference between 0.12.15 and 0.12.16 does narrow this down a bit, and we should refactor and add some tests to the code that you point to.

issue.title: lib/model: Correct handling of multiple subs when scanning (ref #2851)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
### Purpose

Previously the code failed in that it would return top-level plus a sub, i.e. `["", "foo"]`, and it would consider "usr/lib" a prefix of "usr/libexec" which it is not.

It also makes the function testable, which is nice.
### Testing

Bask in the light of that unit test, man!

body:
This build is a v0.12.20 + a fixed "unifySubs". See if that makes a difference? I suspect the problem here is that `index.txt` is a prefix of `index.txt.sig` which should be fixed here.

http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing-branch/226/

The build failed due to a test in the v0.12 code not working on Go 1.6, but the artefacts should be good anyway.

http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing-branch/226/artifact/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/

Ok, I've fired up that build and am using the proper version of syncthing-inotify on the test machine.

```
peter@overcee[ 2:33AM]~/Sync-1174> touch foo.txt foo.txt.sig
...
[OK] 02:35:32 Syncthing is indexing change in default: [foo.txt foo.txt.sig]
...
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:35:32.319990 walk.go:100: DEBUG: Walk /home/peter/Sync/ [foo.txt foo.txt.sig] 131072 &{[] true 0xc8222514e0 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc82022c360 0xc8223a7f60}
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:35:32.320120 walk.go:488: DEBUG: checkDir /home/peter/Sync/ &{Sync 195 2147484096 {63593890531 812944000 0x112e300} {712342500 2636426 16832 21 433 433 4294967295 {1412910059 929565437} {1458293731 812944000} {1458293731 812944000} 195 81 16384 2048 0 0 {1412910059 929565437}}}

[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:35:32.320398 walk.go:319: DEBUG: to hash: foo.txt File{Name:"foo.txt", Flags:0644, Modified:1458293731, Version:[{M2XGECJ 7}], Size:0, Blocks:[]}

peter@overcee[ 2:35AM]~/Sync-1175> rm foo.txt foo.txt.sig
...
[OK] 02:36:41 Syncthing is indexing change in default: [foo.txt foo.txt.sig]
...
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:36:41.087575 walk.go:100: DEBUG: Walk /home/peter/Sync/ [foo.txt foo.txt.sig] 131072 &{[] true 0xc8222514e0 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc82022c360 0xc8223a7f60}
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:36:41.087662 walk.go:488: DEBUG: checkDir /home/peter/Sync/ &{Sync 193 2147484096 {63593890600 580706000 0x112e300} {712342500 2636426 16832 21 433 433 4294967295 {1412910059 929565437} {1458293800 580706000} {1458293800 580706000} 193 81 16384 2048 0 0 {1412910059 929565437}}}
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:36:41.087740 walk.go:214: DEBUG: error: /home/peter/Sync/foo.txt <nil> lstat /home/peter/Sync/foo.txt: no such file or directory
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:36:41.087779 walk.go:214: DEBUG: error: /home/peter/Sync/foo.txt.sig <nil> lstat /home/peter/Sync/foo.txt.sig: no such file or directory
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:36:41.087869 walk.go:167: DEBUG: Walk progress done /home/peter/Sync/ [foo.txt foo.txt.sig] 131072 &{[] true 0xc8222514e0 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc82022c360 0xc8223a7f60}
```

Repeating this part works as expected now, so that's an improvement.

However..

```
peter@overcee[ 2:41AM]~/Sync-1184> touch foo.txt foo.txt.sig
peter@overcee[ 2:41AM]~/Sync-1185> touch bar.txt bar.txt.sig
...

[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:41:39.765009 walk.go:214: DEBUG: error: /home/peter/Sync/foo.txt.sig <nil> lstat /home/peter/Sync/foo.txt.sig: no such file or directory

-rw-r--r--   1 peter  peter         0 Mar 18 02:41 foo.txt.sig
-rw-r--r--   1 peter  peter         0 Mar 18 02:41 foo.txt
local machine:
peter@overcee[ 2:47AM]~/Sync-1027> fetch -q -o - 'http://localhost:8384/rest/db/browse?folder=default' | json_pp | egrep '(foo|bar).txt'
   "foo.txt" : [
   "foo.txt.sig" : [
```

In the second sample, I did as separate steps:

```
touch bar.txt bar.txt.sig
touch foo.txt foo.txt.sig
... pause ...
rm foo* bar*
```

and "foo.txt" and "foo.txt.sig" got left behind.  You can see the syncthing trace show it was looking at them.

If I hit 'rescan' on the 'default' folder in the gui, then:

```
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:49:42.520144 walk.go:100: DEBUG: Walk /home/peter/Sync/ [] 131072 &{[] true 0xc821df4ae0 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc8217aa240 0xc8230a7450}
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:49:42.520255 walk.go:488: DEBUG: checkDir /home/peter/Sync/ &{Sync 193 2147484096 {63593890899 259240000 0x112e300} {712342500 2636426 16832 21 433 433 4294967295 {1412910059 929565437} {1458294099 259240000} {1458294099 259240000} 193 81 16384 2048 0 0 {1412910059 929565437}}}
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:49:42.520648 walk.go:246: DEBUG: ignored: .stfolder
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:49:42.710836 walk.go:167: DEBUG: Walk progress done /home/peter/Sync/ [] 131072 &{[] true 0xc821df4ae0 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc8217aa240 0xc8230a7450}
```

and on the remote side the files disappear, and the disappear from the browse json output.

So there's still a problem.  The simple case appears fixed though.

syncthing: v0.12.20+1-g67a6f81, FreeBSD 64 bit/amd64.
syncthing-inotify: v0.6.8

It doesn't seem to be dependent on doing the group of files as a single step either.  With shell, syncthing-inotify logs ("[OK]") and syncthing trace ("[M2XGE]") interleaved in order:

```
peter@overcee[ 2:58AM]~/Sync-1197> touch foo.txt foo.txt.sig bar.txt bar.txt.sig
...
[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:59:21.162739 walk.go:100: DEBUG: Walk /home/peter/Sync/ [bar.txt bar.txt.sig foo.txt foo.txt.sig] 131072 &{[] true 0xc821df4ae0 d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e 0xc8217aa240 0xc8230a7450}

[M2XGE] 2016/03/18 02:59:21.163246 walk.go:304: DEBUG: rescan: File{Name:"foo.txt", Flags:010644, Modified:1458295095, Version:[{M2XGECJ 18}], Size:128, Blocks:[]} 1458295160 -rw-r--r--
```
